events.text:
Made by Valov Games Studios

Main programmer - Megahorosh
Souls-like stuff programmer - Saltein

actions.text: Move the camera away from the player, for a cinematographic start.
Reduce the height of all billboards, so their textures are perfectly centered.

children.text: Randomize the texture and height of each wall in the layout, resulting in a more dynamic environment.
First texture option.
Second texture option.
Third texture option.
Fourth texture option.
Wait 7 seconds before destroying the tutorial text, giving the player enough time to read it.
Constantly update the camera position to follow the player.

actions.text: Also calculate and store the player shooting angle, which is the angle between the player and the mouse cursor.
At last, mirror the player based on which side of the player the mouse cursor is.

children.text: Move the player depending on the received input.
Move the player left.
Move the player right.
Move the player up.
Move the player down.
If the player moving speed is higher than 16, set its animation to "Walking".
Otherwise, set its animation back to "Idle".
How many degrees a spell can deviate from its intended angle of motion.
While the left mouse button is down, shoot spells towards the mouse position.

actions.text: The angle of motion may vary based on the "SPREAD" value.

children.text: If a bullet collides with a solid object, destroy the bullet.
If the hit object is a crate, only destroy the bullet if the crate really is a solid (solid behavior). Crates above the ground level have the solid behavior set to disabled, so they can't be hit.
If the hit object is a crystal, also reduce 1 from its heath.
If the crystal heath reaches 0, destroy it and create a few particles around it.

actions.text: Also create a very long beam, like a powerful laser shooting towards the sky.

children.text: After a crystal is destroyed, count how many are left on the layout and open the doors that require an equal or lower amount of crystals.
Once a spell is destroyed, leave a single particle on its position.
While a spell is moving in the air, leave a trail of particles behind it.
Create a specific amount of particles in any X/Y position.
How far the particle will move from its origin point.
The direction the particle will move towards.
How long it will take for the particle to reach its destination.

actions.text: Randomize and apply multiple parameters to each particle, resulting in a more dynamic effect.

children.text: How long it takes for a monster to jump from point to point.
How long the monster need to rest before performing another jump.
The distance between the monster and the player.
The angle between the monster and the player.
If the monster has line of sight to the player, make it jump towards the player. But only if the monster is ready to perform a jump.

actions.text: Prevent the monster from jumping again.
Calculate the angle and distance towards the player.
Move the monster using the previously stored values.
Start a cooldown timer, so the monster need to wait a bit before performing another jump.
Reduce the monster size, so the jump looks more intense.
Leave a few green particles behind the monster.

children.text: If the monster isn't jumping and is too close to the player, it's game over.
Once the jump is over, reset the monster size.
Once the cooldown is also over, allow the monster to jump again.
If a spell collides with a monster, change the spell angle of motion slightly to simulate a ricochet effect.
Once the player collides with the trigger, destroy the trigger itself and all monsters in the layout.
Also restart the layout after 3 seconds.
